DEB Stylized Fact: Metabolic rate increases with body mass, but not proportionally – it follows an allometric relationship (typically scales as $\propto$ mass$^{3/4}$).
There is a relationship between body mass and lifespan: larger animals grow slower and live longer.
Food intake capacity is limited by body surface area, while maintenance needs are proportional to volume.
Time to puberty and total lifespan increase with body mass – so-called life-history invariants.
Maximum assimilation rate scales with body mass to a power less than 1.
Maintenance rate per unit structure is constant within species, but varies between species.
Reproductive output scales with body mass through the same power as basal metabolism.
Assimilation efficiency decreases with size due to geometric constraints.
Surface area-to-volume ratio determines metabolic constraints for material transport and heat.
Allometric exponent for heart rate is negative ($\sim$-0.25).
Breathing rate scales negatively with body mass across species.
Blood circulation time increases with body size due to longer transport distances.
Metabolic scope (difference between maximum and resting metabolic rate) scales with body mass.
Digestive tract length scales with body mass and dietary requirements.
Brain mass scales differently from body mass, typically with a lower allometric exponent.
Kidney filtration rate scales with metabolic rate and body mass.
Bone strength scales with body mass to ensure structural integrity.
Muscle mass proportion decreases with increasing body size in most taxa.
Heat production rate scales with metabolic rate and affects thermoregulatory strategies.
Oxygen consumption rate per unit mass decreases with increasing body size.
Swimming speed in aquatic animals scales positively with body length.
Flight metabolic rate in birds scales differently from terrestrial locomotion costs.
Dive duration in aquatic mammals scales with body mass and oxygen storage capacity.
Territory size scales with body mass and energy requirements in many species.
Foraging range increases with body size to meet elevated energy demands.
Daily energy expenditure scales with body mass but varies with activity patterns.
Seasonal fat storage capacity scales with body mass and climate adaptations.
Hibernation metabolic depression is more pronounced in smaller mammals.
Migration distance correlates with body size and energy storage capabilities.
Immune system investment scales with body mass and pathogen exposure risk.
Wound healing rate decreases with body size due to circulatory constraints.
Sensory organ size scales differently from body mass depending on function.
Reproductive organ size scales with body mass and mating system characteristics.
Gestation time increases with body mass and offspring development requirements.
Litter size typically decreases with increasing maternal body mass.
Parental care duration scales with offspring development time and body size.
Age at first reproduction increases with adult body size across taxa.
Maximum population density decreases with average individual body mass.
Home range size scales with body mass and resource distribution patterns.
Dispersal distance correlates with body size and habitat fragmentation.
Predator-prey mass ratios follow predictable scaling relationships.
Trophic level position correlates with body size in food webs.
Biomass turnover rate decreases with increasing organism size.
Population growth rate scales negatively with body mass.
Extinction risk correlates with body size through population size effects.
Metabolic cold adaptation involves changes in allometric relationships.
Altitude adaptation affects metabolic scaling due to oxygen availability.
Aquatic vs terrestrial environments impose different scaling constraints.
Developmental temperature affects adult allometric relationships.

Seasonal changes in body mass alter temporary allometric relationships.
Aging affects metabolic scaling through changes in body composition.
Diet quality influences the scaling of digestive system components.
Social organization affects metabolic scaling through cooperative behaviors.
Parasitism alters host metabolic scaling relationships.
Symbiotic relationships modify allometric patterns in partner organisms.
Habitat complexity influences locomotor scaling relationships.
Predation pressure affects the evolution of size-related traits and scaling.
Competition intensity scales with body size overlap between species.
Resource availability influences optimal body size and scaling patterns.
Climate variability affects size-related adaptations and allometric relationships.
Island environments often lead to altered scaling relationships.
Urbanization impacts metabolic scaling through environmental changes.
Pollution exposure affects size-dependent physiological processes.
Conservation status correlates with body size through multiple mechanisms.
Phylogenetic constraints influence the evolution of allometric relationships.
Developmental plasticity allows modification of scaling relationships.
Life history strategies reflect different solutions to scaling constraints.
Biomechanical limits impose constraints on size-related performance scaling.
Physiological limits determine maximum achievable body sizes in different taxa.
Cellular size constraints influence tissue-level scaling relationships.

Network topology affects scaling of circulatory and nervous systems.
Scaling relationships differ between growth phases and adult maintenance.
Environmental stress modifies normal allometric relationships.
